## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 103, 640, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space, \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space, \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space, \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge, \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant, \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass constant, \(u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron, \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton, \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant, \(R = 8.31 \mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant, \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant, \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant, \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall, \(g = 9.81 \mathrm{ms}^{- 2}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 102, 618, 121]]<|/det|>
\[c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 168, 89]]<|/det|>
## Formulae

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 160, 275, 177]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 265, 285, 281]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 298, 285, 314]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 331, 311, 348]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 106, 556, 141]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 160, 522, 176]]<|/det|>
\[W = p\Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 191, 532, 220]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 228, 515, 245]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 256, 572, 287]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V} < c^2 >\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 295, 534, 312]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 327, 606, 365]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_0\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_0^2 - x^2)}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 377, 534, 410]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[426, 428, 621, 448]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_1 + 1 / C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 466, 591, 485]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_1 + C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 500, 524, 523]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 536, 591, 556]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_1 + R_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[426, 572, 621, 591]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_1 + 1 / R_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 607, 556, 625]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_0\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 641, 580, 660]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_0\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 675, 532, 710]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[297, 72, 700, 91]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided.

<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 710, 121]]<|/det|>
State two SI base units other than the kilogram, metre and second.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 173, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>1.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 133, 875, 153]]<|/det|>
<form>................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 163, 875, 183]]<|/det|>

<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 210, 146, 229]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 210, 875, 244]]<|/det|>
A metal wire has original length \(l_0\). It is then suspended and hangs vertically as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 252, 631, 368]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 386, 532, 405]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 418, 875, 452]]<|/det|>
The weight of the wire causes it to stretch. The elastic potential energy stored in the wire is \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 465, 181, 484]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 465, 579, 484]]<|/det|>
Show that the SI base units of \(E\) are \(\mathrm{kgm}^2 \mathrm{s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 591, 875, 609]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 73, 180, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 536, 92]]<|/det|>
The elastic potential energy \(E\) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 102, 561, 123]]<|/det|>
\[E = C\rho^{2}g^{2}A l_{0}^{3}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 134, 485, 153]]<|/det|>
where \(\rho\) is the density of the metal,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[248, 149, 510, 168]]<|/det|>
\(g\) is the acceleration of free fall,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[248, 164, 579, 183]]<|/det|>
\(A\) is the cross-sectional area of the wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 181, 380, 199]]<|/det|>
and \(C\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 211, 475, 229]]<|/det|>
Determine the SI base units of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 415, 875, 435]]<|/det|>
<form>SI base units of \(C\)  ...................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 875, 122]]<|/det|>
A source of radio waves sends a pulse towards a reflector. The pulse returns from the reflector and is detected at the same point as the source. The emitted and reflected pulses are recorded on a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.) as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[897, 78, 945, 120]]<|/det|>

A variable force \(F\) acts to the left on the trolley as it moves between points P and Q.

Two parallel forces each of \(35\mathrm{N}\) act on the edge of the wheel in the vertical directions shown in Fig. 4.1. Friction between the pin and the wheel is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 875, 168]]<|/det|>
A power supply of e.m.f. \(240\mathrm{V}\) and zero internal resistance is connected to a heater as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 177, 695, 343]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 361, 532, 380]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 392, 875, 443]]<|/det|>
The wires used to connect the heater to the power supply each have length \(75\mathrm{m}\). The wires have a cross-sectional area \(2.5\mathrm{mm}^2\) and resistivity \(18\mathrm{n}\Omega \mathrm{m}\). The heater has a constant resistance of \(38\Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 456, 183, 475]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 454, 586, 473]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[505, 715, 875, 734]]<|/det|>
